cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the Spanish language for beginning students; overview of basic grammatical structures, development of vocabulary and oral and written expression. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Spanish for Beginners
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: No previous knowledge of Spanish, or placement test results.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SPA120Y1, SPA219Y1, SPA319Y1, SPA220Y1, SPA320Y1, SPA420H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students registering for their first Spanish course and unsure of the appropriate level, must visit spanport.utoronto.ca and complete the placement test or contact the Department of Spanish and Portuguese. Students who enroll in a course not suitable to their language proficiency will be allocated in a more appropriate one. Students must enroll in one of the mandatory tutorial sections that correspond to their lecture.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials are live-streamed, delivered synchronously per the meeting schedule. Students need a webcam, a microphone, and the ability to use Bb Collaborate / MS Teams.

courses.name: Accelerated Spanish Through Community Engaged Learning

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is a combination of SPA100Y1 and SPA220Y1 into one year. It is designed for students with prior knowledge of Spanish, but whose level is not appropriate to enroll in SPA220Y1. The focus is on the fundamentals of Spanish grammar and cultural aspects through community service learning with the local Spanish-speaking community of Toronto. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Accelerated Spanish Through Community Engaged Learning
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: High School Spanish; informal knowledge of Spanish
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Native and Heritage Speakers, SPA219Y1, SPA100Y1 and SPA220Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students registering for their first Spanish course and unsure of the appropriate level, must visit spanport.utoronto.ca and complete the placement test or contact the Department of Spanish and Portuguese. Students who enroll in a course not suitable to their language proficiency will be allocated in a more appropriate one. Students must enroll in one of the mandatory tutorial sections that correspond to their lecture.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are pre-recorded and delivered asynchronously online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Students need a microphone, Conversify and ability to use Bb Collaborate. To be sure about your eligibility for this course, please contact the course instructor at juancarlos.rochaosornio@utoronto.ca. Students will complete 30 hours of placement throughout the year as part of experiential learning component (additional to regular course contact hours) in local community organizations serving the Spanish-speaking community of Toronto and the GTA.  Placements will be conducted online only.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Dec 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: A deep dive into the modern experience of one of the world´s most compelling cities, this course considers Barcelona from a multidisciplinary perspective that includes study of its architecture, foodways, politics and response to mass tourism. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Barcelona

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: During the lifetime of Miguel de Cervantes, the Spanish monarchy governed an empire that extended across the globe, from its traditional lands in Europe to colonies in the Philippines and the Americas. We will examine the advantages and cost of imperial rule through reading Cervantes's Exemplary Stories (1613), and diverse collection of short fictional texts. Discussions will centre on such questions as the social impact of imperial wealth, the relationship between external wars and the ideal of peaceful rule, and contact with non-European cultures. Students will be introduced to the University of Toronto´s outstanding resources for studying the literatures and cultures of early modern Europe. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cervantes and Imperial Spain

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: For native (heritage) speakers who have had exposure to spoken Spanish in an informal context (i.e, living in a Spanish-speaking country; or with a Spanish-speaking family), but little to no exposure to written Spanish. The students' ability to speak and understand Spanish may range from basic to relatively high fluency, but they cannot write and/or read Spanish. The course reviews English/Spanish spelling differences; written and spoken registers of Spanish, and basic aspects of the grammatical system. Provides students with the essential understanding of Spanish grammatical system; builds their vocabulary; and trains them to express themselves formally.
cmCourseInfo.title: Academic Spanish
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Basic to relatively high native ability to speak and understand Spanish; limited or no formal education in Spanish.

notes.name: Course Note

Students must enroll in one of the mandatory tutorial sections that correspond to their lecture.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed, delivered synchronously online per the meeting schedule. Students need a webcam, a microphone, and the ability to use Bb Collaborate / MS Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: Intermediate Spanish for non-native speakers. Intensive grammar review of the structures of Spanish integrated with an introduction to reading authentic Spanish material, with practice designed to build vocabulary and to improve oral and written expression.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Spanish
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA100Y1 or placement test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

Students registering for their first Spanish course and unsure of the appropriate level, must visit spanport.utoronto.ca and complete the placement test or contact the Department of Spanish and Portuguese. Students who enroll in a course not suitable to their language proficiency will be allocated in a more appropriate one. Delivery Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description: A practical introduction to articulatory phonetics, Spanish sound patterns, phonetics, phonology; the basic concepts of phonetic description and transcription; the study of Spanish vowel and consonant systems, stress and intonation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Spanish Pronunciation
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA100Y1
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SPA219Y1; native speakers of Spanish; SPA321H1

notes.name: Course Note

It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to university literary studies in Spanish and information literacy. Representative selection of Spanish and Spanish American prose, poetry, and drama, with focus on critical terminology and methods of literary analysis. Required for a program degree.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Hispanic Literary Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: First semester SPA220Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered synchronously online. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Forms of cultural expression in Spain, Latin America and Spanish-speaking North America, with study of representative media, including literature, journalism, film, visual art, and the urban environment. Introduction to methods of cultural analysis. (Offered in alternate years).
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Hispanic Cultural Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum 1st semester of SPA220Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded, and delivered asynchronously online. Class will meet for one hour of live discussion at specified times within the meeting schedule. Students need a webcam, a microphone, and the ability to use Bb Collaborate / MS Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced Spanish for non-natives. Selective review of grammar with emphasis on the complex sentence; intensive practice in written and oral expression to improve proficiency.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Spanish
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or placement test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students must enroll in one of the mandatory tutorial sections that correspond to their lecture. Students registering for their first Spanish course and unsure of the appropriate level, must visit spanport.utoronto.ca and complete the placement test or contact the Department of Spanish and Portuguese. Students who enroll in a course not suitable to their language proficiency will be allocated in a more appropriate one.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials are live-streamed, delivered synchronously per the meeting schedule. Students need a webcam, a microphone, and the ability to use Bb Collaborate / MS Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: The basic concepts and analytic tools of linguistics applied to the study of Spanish, with a focus on the Spanish phonological, morphological, and syntactic systems. Theoretical discussion and practical exercises in analytic techniques.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Hispanic Linguistics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or SPA219Y1; or instructor's permission

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed, delivered synchronously per the meeting schedule. Wednesday lectures will be recorded to permit asynchronous attendance. Students need a webcam, a microphone, and the ability to use Bb Collaborate / MS Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced level business Spanish course covering topics on international relations, politics, legal and culture. This course aims to enhance written and oral expression in Spanish through content focusing on the language that is used in official, diplomatic, and financial situations. Through the analysis of case studies, newspapers and videos, students will be introduced to the business cultures and intercultural communication of the Spanish-speaking world.
cmCourseInfo.title: Business Spanish
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or proof of comparable Spanish level
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: SPA320Y1, SPA219Y1 or proof of comparable Spanish level

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students must enroll in the mandatory tutorial on ACORN.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded, and delivered asynchronously online. Class will meet for one hour of live discussion at specified times within the meeting schedule. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: Latin American Varieties of Spanish Through the Media

cmCourseInfo.description: This course aims at exposing students to different varieties of Latin American Spanish. Lexical, morpho-syntactic and phonological variation will be discussed and theoretical descriptions will be illustrated by using samples from contemporary cinema and television. (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Latin American Varieties of Spanish Through the Media
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or SPA219Y1 or Permission of the Department

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Literary and artistic movements in Spain from 1890 to 1940, with special attention to the convergence and mutual mediation of politics and art. Materials to be studied include novels, poetry, the urban environment, graphic art, literary journals and manifestos, and some early Hispanic film. (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Modernist Movements in Spain
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or SPA219Y1 or Permission of the Department

courses.name: Court and Country in Early Modern Spain

cmCourseInfo.description: Representative texts (such as ballads, popular and courtly lyric; chivalry, pastoral and picaresque prose, theater) from the early modern period, studied in relation to the history and society of imperial Spain. Discussion of literary texts as codes of social conduct; issues of urbanization, court culture, social order and disorder, and cultural discourses of identity and difference. Reading from modern authors (Sender, Borges) to illustrate the continuity of court and country in the Hispanic tradition. (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Court and Country in Early Modern Spain
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or SPA219Y1 or Permission of the Department

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: This online course examines the social, political, and cultural contexts of recent Latin American cinema. Topics include: military dictatorship and its aftermath, race and indigeneity; poverty, precarity, and inequality; gender and sexuality; and memory and trauma. The representation of these themes in Latin American cinema of the 21st century has contributed to an increase in its transnational and cosmopolitan reception. Focus is given to Argentina and Mexico, though films from other countries will be included. Taught in English.
cmCourseInfo.title: Latin American Cinema

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are pre-recorded and delivered online. Learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Students need a webcam, a microphone, and the ability to use Quercus / Bb Collaborate.

courses.name: Spanish American Women in Art, Film, and Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: Study of different creative expressions by women in Spanish America from the colonial period to the present; analysis of selected works of visual art, film, essays, poetry, and fiction. (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Spanish American Women in Art, Film, and Literature
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or SPA219Y1 or Permission of the Department

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed, delivered synchronously per the meeting schedule. Students need a webcam, a microphone, and the ability to use Bb Collaborate / MS Teams.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 23, 2020: Room added.

cmCourseInfo.description: Considers continuities and divisions between word and action, art and politics, in short works of fiction, theatre, film and performance projects. Includes work from twentieth-century and contemporary Mexico as well as Latin American cultural production from Canada and the United States.
cmCourseInfo.title: Latin American Performative Expression
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or SPA219Y1 or Permission of the Department
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SPA467H1 (Topics: Latin American Performative Practices), offered in Fall 2009, Winter 2018

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Linguistic analysis with the objective of improving students' command of Spanish grammar. Advanced review of traditional grammatical topics, including the verbal and pronominal systems, and Spanish copulas and embedded clauses. This course assumes familiarity with the grammatical terminology introduced in SPA320Y1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Grammar
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA219Y1 or SPA320Y1, or placement test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Theoretical and experimental approaches to Spanish phonology. Topics include: Spanish phonemic inventory, sound patterns, suprasegmentals (stress and intonation), synchronic and diachronic variation. Methods of data collection and analysis in the discipline, with practical applications. (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Spanish Phonology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA322H1 or permission of the Department

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed, delivered synchronously per the meeting schedule. Students need Excel, a webcam, a microphone, and the ability to use Bb Collaborate / MS Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: Have you ever doubted where Spanish came from? Or how did it become the language we know today? This course presents a detailed study of the external and internal history of the Spanish language in which this evolution occurred. Special attention will be paid to the linguistic progress of the language from its Latin roots to Modern Spanish and to the socio-cultural, historical, political and literary influence that have affected its linguistic evolution. The main features of the Spanish language evolution will be put in practice through a close reading of representative Medieval, Renaissance and dialectal texts.
cmCourseInfo.title: History of the Spanish Language
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA320Y1 or SPA219Y1 or permission of instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Detailed study of Don Quixote as a foundational text in the European literary tradition, with attention to the conventions, genres, and literary techniques that inform the text.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cervantes: Don Quixote
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA258H1; SPA219Y1 or SPA320Y1 or permission of the department

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: The end of civil and military conflicts in the last decade of the 20th century reshapes the political landscape of Central America. Through selected readings of novels and short stories from representative writers, issues of immigration, displacement, and globalization are discussed to understand these changes in the region. (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Central America Postwar Narrative
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least one 300-series half-course in Spanish.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed, delivered synchronously per the meeting schedule. Students need a webcam, a microphone, and the ability to use Bb Collaborate / MS Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: Individual study with a member of staff on a topic of common interest including readings, discussion and written assignments. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Study
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least one 300-series half-course in Spanish, and written approval of the Undergraduate Coordinator
